title: Tampon tax held up Brexit negotiations, but when will it be scrapped?
text:
Most things sold in the UK are subject to VAT. Exclusions apply for anything deemed a “necessity”, which includes most food and children’s clothes. A lot of things that aren't vital for life are also exempt, like zoo tickets, gambling and private jets.

Bizarrely, tampons and pads, although a necessity for half the population over their lifetime, are not included in that category - and instead are subject to a five per cent tax rate.

Women have been campaigning for years to scrap this 'luxury' VAT on menstrual products - in 2015, student protesters delivered a petition to ‘#EndTamponTax’ to Downing Street ,calling for the UK government to stop classifying sanitary products as 'luxuries.’
